questions.text: A 10 y/o girl presents with a sore throat, low-grade fever, and swollen neck glands. Examination reveals a thick greyish membrane covering her tonsils. Which among the following is the most suitable culture medium for confirming the diagnosis at the earliest stage?
questions.explanation:
Culture Media

Colony appearance

Evaluation

Loeffler’s serum slope
  • Small
  • Circular opaque disks
  • Glistening,
  • White with a yellow tinge
  • Advantage: Growth can be detected as early as 6–8 hours.
  • The best medium for metachromatic granule production
  • Disadvantage: Supports the growth of other throat commensals also

Potassium tellurite agar

(McLeod’s and Hoyle’s-modified PTA)

(Options A, C&D ruled out)
  • Grey or black colour
  • Advantage: Throat commensals are inhibited
  • Disadvantage: Colonies appear only after 48 hours of incubation

Sheep blood agar
  • Small
  • Circular
  • White
  • Sometimes hemolytic(mitis biotype)
  • Differentiate colonies from streptococcal or staphylococcal pharyngitis, which may simulate diphtheria.
  • The serum slope may show growth in 4-8 hours but, if negative, will have to be incubated for 24 hours

questions.text: A 6 y/o child presents with a sore throat, low-grade fever, and a greyish membrane covering the tonsils. The doctor suspects diphtheria. Which diagnostic test is used for confirming the production of diphtheria toxin by C.diptheriae?
questions.explanation:
Test

Features

Elek’s gel precipitation test

gel precipitation test" data-author="" data-hash="9889" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/duP7wodTOR1trhtzKtWV1744446503.png" />
  • Immunodiffusion in gel.
  • The strain isolated is streaked onto a media containing a filter paper soaked with antitoxin.
  • If the strain is toxigenic, it liberates the toxin which diffuses in the agar and meets with the antitoxin to produce an arrow-shaped precipitation band.
  • Used to know the relatedness between the strains isolated during an outbreak.

Schicks test
  • Based on the ability of circulating antitoxin to neutralize the diphtheria toxin given intradermally
  • Indicates immunity or susceptibility to the disease.

Tissue culture test
  • The toxigenicity can be demonstrated by incorporating the strains in the agar overlay of cell culture monolayers.
  • The toxin produced diffuses into the cells below and causes lysis of the cells

PCR
  • Detection of Toxin gene (tox) has been developed to detect the presence of genes coding for the toxin, in clinical isolates

ELISA
  • Detect toxins from the patient's isolate using an antitoxin and enzyme-substrate system.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Nocardia and Actinomyces is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Actinomyces infections are endogenous, whereas Nocardia infections are exogenous.

options.label: B
options.text: Actinomyces is nonacid-fast, while Nocardia is partially acid-fast.

options.label: C
options.text: Penicillin is the preferred treatment for Nocardia infections.

options.label: D
options.text: Nocardia is an obligate aerobe, whereas Actinomyces is anaerobic.

questions.correct_answer: C. Penicillin is the preferred treatment for Nocardia infections.
questions.explanation:
Features

Actinomycetes

Nocardia

Acid-fastness

(Option B ruled out)

Nonacid-fast

Partially acid-fast

O2 Requirement

(Option D ruled out)

Anaerobe

Obligate aerobe

Habitat

(Option A ruled out)
  • Found as oral flora
  • Infections occur endogenously
  • The usual habitat is the soil
  • Infections occur exogenously

Risk factors

Immunocompetent also

Usually only in immunocompromised

Clinical forms

Cervicofascial, abdominal, and others.

Pulmonary, CNS forms, Actinomycetoma

Granules

Sulfur granules are hard and not emulsifiable, consist of branching filamentous bacilli, and are surrounded by clubs (sun-ray appearance)
  • Granules are soft and lobulated and also show a sun-ray appearance
  • Commonly found in mycetoma, rare in other conditions

Culture
  • Spidery molar teeth colony in solid media
  • Fluffy ball at the bottom of the liquid medium
  • Colonies are creamy, wrinkled, and pink Isolation is done in
  • Selective media
  • Paraffin bait technique
  • LJ medium

Treatment

(Option C)

Penicillin

Cotrimoxazole

questions.text: A microbiologist cultivates a sample from a patient suspected of having a Corynebacterium infection. The bacteria grow slowly on standard media but grow well in a medium containing lipids. Which Corynebacterium species is likely being cultured?
questions.explanation:
Group

Growth Characteristics

Example Species

Lipophilic

Grow slowly on standard media; enhanced by lipids
  • C. jeikeium
  • C. urealyticum (Option B)

Non-lipophilic

Grow well on standard laboratory media
  • C. striatum (Option A ruled out)
  • C. amycolatum
  • C. pseudodiphtheriticum
  • C. pseudotuberculosis (Option C ruled out)
  • C. ulcerans (Option D ruled out)
  • C. minutissimum

Species

Lipophilicity

Characteristics

C. pseudotuberculosis

Non-Lipophilic
  • Infection in cows, transmitted via milk.
  • Erythromycin sensitivity
  • Diphtheria antitoxin is a protective

C. minutissimum

Non-Lipophilic
  • Erythrasma rash in axilla and groin
  • These lesions demonstrate coral red fluorescence on Wood's lamp evaluation

C.jeikeium

Lipophilic
  • Infections of the cutaneous and vascular system.
  • High mortality rate
  • Immunocompromised host
  • Multidrug resistance and responds only to vancomycin

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes diphtheria toxin (DT) based on the provided information?

options.label: A
options.text: DT, a DNA virus, integrates its tox gene into Corynebacterium diphtheriae, allowing toxin production.

options.label: B
options.text: The iron concentration in the blood affects DT production.

options.label: C
options.text: DT enters host cells by binding to DNA, which triggers direct cell lysis.

options.label: D
options.text: C.diptheriae spreads throughout the bloodstream, causing both bacteremia and toxaemia.

questions.correct_answer: B. The iron concentration in the blood affects DT production.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Production and Structure
  • DT is a protein exotoxin produced by the toxigenic Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Consists of two fragments(Bipartite), A and B, with a molecular weight of approximately 62,000 daltons. (Option C ruled out)

Role of Lysogenic β-phage
  • The tox gene is carried by a lysogenic β-phage.
  • Only phage-infected strains produce toxin; nontoxigenic strains can become toxigenic if infected.
  • Corynebacterium diphtheriae remains localized at the infection site, with only the toxin entering circulation, causing toxaemia but not bacteremia.(Option D ruled out)

Mechanism of Action
  • Fragment B binds host cell receptors, facilitating fragment A entry into the cytoplasm.
  • Fragment A catalyses ADP-ribosylation of EF-2, halting protein synthesis.

Potency
  • The lethal dose for a 250g guinea pig: is 0.0001 mg.
  • The estimated lethal dose for humans: 130 ng/kg body weight.

Systemic Effects
  • DT spreads via blood, causing myocarditis and neuritis.
  • Myocarditis is potentially fatal.

Factors Affecting Production
  • Influenced by environmental factors: alkaline pH (7.8-8.0), oxygen, and iron concentration in the growth medium.
  • High production with low iron availability (0.1 mg/l); iron addition inhibits production (0.5 mg/l).

Toxoid Formation
  • Treatment with formalin (0.2-0.4%), and incubation at 37°C for 4-6 weeks converts DT to toxoid.
  • Toxoid lacks toxicity but induces an immune response; used in vaccines.

Immunity
  • Immunity is primarily mediated by antitoxin antibodies neutralizing DT.

questions.text: A child presented with a sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes in the neck. Throat culture was subjected to Albert's stain and revealed bacilli arranged in a Chinese letter pattern. The patient's condition deteriorates rapidly, with signs of severe respiratory distress. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for the clinical manifestations seen in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Cleavage of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).

options.label: B
options.text: Inactivation of elongation factor 2 (EF-2) by Exotoxin A.

options.label: C
options.text: Binding of fragment B to human cell receptors by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).

options.label: D
options.text: Secretion of toxins by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

questions.correct_answer: C. Binding of fragment B to human cell receptors by Diphtheria Toxin (DT).
questions.explanation:
Toxin

Source

Mechanism of Action

Diphtheria Toxin (DT)

Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  • Secreted by bacteria infected with tox-carrying β-phage.
  • Cleaved into fragments B and A.
  • Fragment B binds to human cell receptors.
  • Fragment A ADP-ribosylates elongation factor 2 (EF-2), halting protein synthesis.

Exotoxin A

Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Secreted by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Inhibits protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells.
  • The mechanism involves a similar process to DT, disrupting EF-2 function.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe swelling of the neck, along with difficulty swallowing. O/E there was a grey-white pseudomembrane in the throat. Which of the following bacteria is most likely responsible for these clinical findings?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Features

Complications
  • Sore throat
  • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia)
  • Low-grade fever
  • Pseudomembrane formation in the throat
  • Non-healing ulcers covered by grey membrane on the skin
  • Myocarditis
  • Neurological complications (e.g., paralysis, neuropathy)
  • Renal failure
  • Airway obstruction

questions.text: A 7 y/o presents with a sore throat, low-grade fever, and difficulty swallowing. O/E, he has a greyish membrane covering his tonsils and swollen cervical lymph nodes. Which investigation helps to identify the presence of volutin granules in a case of suspected diphtheria?
questions.explanation:
Type

Components

Function

Albert Solution 1
  • Malachite Green for organism staining
  • Toluidine Blue for metachromatic staining
  • Enhances contrast and specificity in staining.

Albert Solution 2
  • Iodine
  • Specifically targets volutin or Babes-Ernst granules.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought in for vaccination. The paediatrician recommends administering the first dose of the DPT vaccine. Which among the following statements is false regarding the DPT vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: DPT is given at the anterolateral aspect of the thigh..

options.label: B
options.text: Thiomersal is used as a preservative.

options.label: C
options.text: DPT should be kept at 2-8 Celsius.

options.label: D
options.text: The pediatric dose of diphtheria toxoid contains 2 Lf units, whereas the adult dose contains 25 Lf units

questions.correct_answer: D. The pediatric dose of diphtheria toxoid contains 2 Lf units, whereas the adult dose contains 25 Lf units
questions.explanation:
Type

Composition

DPT
  • Dt (Diphtheria Toxoid)
  • Pertussis whole cell
  • TT (Tetanus toxoid)
  • The pertussis component acts as an adjuvant and increases the immunogenicity of DT & TT

DaPT
  • DT
  • TT
  • Acellular pertussis(aP)

Td
  • Tetanus toxoid
  • Adult dose 2Lf of diphtheria toxin

Pentavalent
  • DPT
  • Haemophilus influenza B
  • Hepatitis B

Children

7 doses are given-

  • 3 doses of pentavalent vaccine at 6, 10, and 14 weeks of birth +
  • 2 booster doses of DPT at 16–24 months and 5 years +
  • another 2 booster doses of Td at 10 years and 16 years

Pregnant women

2 doses of Td at 1 month interval

Adults

 
  • >18 years -completed primary vaccination
  • >18 years completed primary vaccination



Td booster dose is indicated every 10 years till 65 years.
3 doses of Td given at 0, 1 month, and 1 year

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and a thick grey membrane extending to the nasopharynx. Given these clinical features, what would be the initial dose of diphtheria antitoxin to administer?
questions.explanation:
Type of Disease

Antitoxin

Early stage <48hrs

20,000-40,000 IM or IV

Nasopharyngeal Disease

40,000-60,000 IM or IV

Extensive disease with neck disease (bull neck) > 3 days

80,000-120,000 half IM or half IV

questions.text: Match the type of diphtheria bacilli biotypes with their characteristic colonies on Tellurite Blood Agar. 1) Gravis a) Poached egg 2) Intermedius b) Daisy's head 3) Mitis c) Frog’s egg
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Gravis

Intermedius

Mitis

Morphology

-Usually short rods, with uniform staining, few or no granules.

-Some degree of pleomorphism, with irregularly barred, snow-shoe and tear-drop forms

Long barred forms with clubbed ends; poor granulation, very pleomorphic

Long, curved, pleomorphic rods with prominent granulation

Colony on tellurite blood agar

-In 18 hours, the colony is 1-2 mm in size, with a greyish-black centre, paler, semitranslucent periphery and commencing crenation of edge.

-In 2-3 days, 3-5 mm in size, flat colony with raised dark centre and crenated edge with radial striation—‘daisy head’ colony

-18-hour colony, small, 1 mm in size, misty.

-Does not enlarge in 48 hours, smoother, more glistening periphery and a lighter ring near the edge—‘frog’s egg’ colony

-Size variable, shiny black.

-In 2-3 days, colonies become flat, with a central elevation—‘poached egg’ colony

Consistency of colonies

Like ‘cold margarine’, brittle, moves as a whole on the plate, not easily picked out or emulsifiable

Intermediate between gravis and mitis

Soft, buttery, easily emulsifiable

Hemolysis

Variable

Non-hemolytic

Usually hemolytic

Growth in broth

Surface pellicle, granular deposit, little or no turbidity

Turbidity in 24 hours, clearing in 48 hours, with fine granular sediment

Diffuse turbidity with soft pellicle later

Glycogen and starch fermentation

Positive

Negative

Negative

questions.text: Which of the following clinical forms of actinomycosis best describes the two given statements? Statement 1- The most common clinical form of actinomycosis Statement 2- Abscesses in bone and soft tissue, with chronic draining sinuses to the exterior
questions.explanation:
Clinical Form

Description

Cervicofacial
  • The most common form- usually presents as a painless, slow-growing hard mass with cutaneous fistulas, commonly known as a lumpy jaw.
  • Indurated lesions on the cheek and submaxillary regions.

Thoracic
  • Lesions in the lung that may involve the pleura and pericardium, spreading outwards through the chest wall

Abdominal
  • Lesions usually around the cecum involving neighbouring tissues and the abdominal wall.
  • Infection can spread to the liver via the portal vein.

Pelvic
  • Often associated with the use of intrauterine devices, producing abscesses in bone and soft tissue, with chronic draining sinuses to the exterior.

questions.text: Which statement about clinical manifestations of Listeria monocytogenes infection is False?

options.label: A
options.text: Pregnant women infected with Listeria monocytogenes may experience flu-like symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: Neonatal listeriosis can present as early-onset or late-onset disease.

options.label: C
options.text: Listeria monocytogenes infection in adults very rarely leads to meningitis.

options.label: D
options.text: Immunocompromised individuals are at higher risk of severe Listeria monocytogenes infections.

questions.correct_answer: C. Listeria monocytogenes infection in adults very rarely leads to meningitis.
questions.explanation:
Listeria monocytogenes

Mode of Transmission
  • Contaminated food
  • Vertical transmission (mother to fetus, during birth)

Common Food Sources
  • Contaminated coleslaw
  • Milk, Soft cheeses
  • "Ready-to-eat" foods (delicatessen meat, uncooked hotdogs)

Age Groups at Risk
  • Neonates
  • Elderly individuals

Increased Risk Factors
  • Use of proton pump inhibitors
  • Pregnant women
  • Immunocompromised individuals

Survival in Food
  • Survives refrigeration (4°C)
  • Found in stored foods (aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk, cold salads)

Infection Type
  • Sporadic
  • Outbreaks can occur

Psychrotrophic
  • L. monocytogenes is a psychrotrophic organism with an optimum growth temperature of 30ºC to 37ºC but has the ability to grow at a wide range of temperatures from 1ºC to 45ºC.

Motility
  • Shows Tumbling and Differential motility(motile at 25.C by forming actin rockets, non motile at 37.C)

Pathogenesis
  • Intracellular survival: lysis of phagosome (listeriolysin O)
  • Host cell actin polymerization (cell membrane approach)
  • Direct cell-to-cell spread (listeriopods)

Clinical Manifestations
  • Neonatal listeriosis: Early-onset and late-onset disease (Option B ruled out)
  • Pregnant women:
    • Granulomatosis infantiseptica in baby in 3rd trimester
    • Fetal complications (abortion, preterm delivery)
    • Maternal complications (flu-like symptoms, bacteremia, rarely meningitis) (Option A ruled out)
  • Adults:
    • Bacteremia and meningitis (elderly, >60 years)
    • Immunosuppression- higher risk (steroid therapy, HIV, diabetes, malignancy) (Option D ruled out)
    • Post-kidney transplant meningitis (1-month post-transplant)
    • Gastroenteritis (consumption of contaminated milk, meat, salads)

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding laboratory diagnosis and characteristics of Listeria monocytogenes is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Shows the tumbling type of motility at 37°C.

options.label: B
options.text: Growth on PALCAM agar is enhanced by the presence of antibiotics.

options.label: C
options.text: The cold enrichment technique involves storing clinical materials at 4°C.

options.label: D
options.text: Experimental inoculation in rabbits causes marked monocytosis.

questions.correct_answer: A. Shows the tumbling type of motility at 37°C.
